Abstract

We propose a federated learning framework to handle heterogeneous client devices which do not conform to the population data distribution. The approach hinges upon a parameterized superquantile-based objective, where the parameter ranges over levels of conformity. We present an optimization algorithm and establish its convergence to a stationary point. We show how to practically implement it using secure aggregation by interleaving iterations of the usual federated averaging method with device filtering. We conclude with numerical experiments on neural networks as well as linear models on tasks from computer vision and natural language processing.

1 Introduction

The proliferation of mobile phones, wearables and edge devices has led to an unprecedented growth in the generation of user interaction data. Systems which tap into the power of this rich data while respecting the privacy of users are geared to lead the next generation of intelligent applications and devices. The leading distributed learning framework in this setting is federated learning [30].

In federated learning, a number of client devices with privacy-sensitive data collaboratively learn a machine learning model under the orchestration of a central server, while keeping their data decentralized. This is achieved by pushing the actual computation to the devices while the server coordinates with the devices for aggregation of model updates. Secure aggregation ensures that no individual device’s updates are known to either the server or other devices [7]. Federated learning has found myriad applications ranging from smartphone apps [46] to healthcare [20].

A key feature of federated learning is statistical heterogeneity, i.e., client data distributions are not identically distributed. Each user has unique characteristics which are reflected in the data they generate. These characteristics are influenced by personal, cultural, regional and geographical factors. For instance, the varied use of language contributes to data heterogeneity in a next word prediction task.

Vanilla federated learning and its de facto standard algorithm, FedAvg [30], aim to fit a model to the population distribution of the devices available for training. While this approach works for users who conform to the population (e.g., trend followers), it is liable to fail on individuals who do not conform to the population, leading to poor user experience. The goal of this work is to present a framework to improve the experience of these diversely non-conforming users without sacrificing the good experience of conforming users.

Diversity of users leads to heterogeneity in the loss functions of the users, which in turn manifests itself as heavy tails in the loss distribution over users. Therefore, a natural approach to handling user heterogeneity consists in building an objective based on upper quantiles, in order to focus on the tail distribution. In particular, we use the superquantile [38] of the loss distribution (i.e., the expectation over its upper tail).

Training with a superquantile-based objective is not straightforward because of its inherent non-smoothness. It is worth emphasizing that any optimization issue can be exacerbated in the federated setting because of the constraints imposed by communication costs and privacy-preserving requirements. Here, we present an algorithm to optimize a superquantile-based objective which overcomes these challenges. It enjoys a time and space complexity which is a constant multiple of the complexity of FedAvg.

Contributions.

We make the following contributions.

  1. (a)

    The ΔΔ\Delta-FL Framework111 pronounced as Simplicial-FL: We introduce the ΔΔ\Delta-FL framework, summarized in Figure 1, to handle heterogeneity of client data distributions. The framework relies on a superquantile-based objective parameterized by the conformity level, which is a scalar summary of how closely a device conforms to the population.

  2. (b)

    Optimization Algorithm: We present an algorithm to optimize the ΔΔ\Delta-FL objective and establish its almost sure convergence to a stationary point. We show how to implement a practical variant of the algorithm with the use of secure aggregation such that it has the same per-iteration communication cost as FedAvg. See Figure 2 for a schematic summary of the algorithm.

  3. (c)

    Numerical Simulations: We demonstrate the breadth of our framework with numerical simulations using neural networks and linear models, on tasks including image classification, language modeling and sentiment analysis based on public datasets. The simulations demonstrate superior performance of ΔΔ\Delta-FL on the upper quantiles of the error on test devices, while being competitive with vanilla federated learning on the mean error. We have released a Python package with scripts to reproduce all simulations [1].

Outline.

Section 2 describes the setting and precisely defines conformity. Section 3 describes the ΔΔ\Delta-FL framework and the training objective. Section 4 describes a provably convergent algorithm to optimize the ΔΔ\Delta-FL objective, and presents a practical variant of the algorithm. Section 5 presents numerical simulations of the proposed method. Section 6 surveys related work. The supplement contains a rigorous presentation of the material with proofs.

2 Problem Setting

Federated learning consists of a number of heterogeneous client devices which collaboratively train a machine learning model. The model is then deployed on all client devices, including those not seen during training. We first review the training setup, followed by test devices.

Concretely, suppose that we have N𝑁N client devices available for training. We characterize each training device by a probability distribution qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k} over some data space 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} and a weight αk>0subscript𝛼𝑘0\alpha_{k}>0. We assume that the data on device k𝑘k are distributed i.i.d. according to qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k} and ∑k=1Nαk=1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝛼𝑘1\sum_{k=1}^{N}\alpha_{k}=1 w.l.o.g.

We measure the loss incurred by a model w∈ℝd𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑w\in\mathbb{R}^{d} on a device with data distribution q𝑞q by

F​(w;q):=𝔼ξ∼q​[f​(w;ξ)],assign𝐹𝑤𝑞subscript𝔼similar-to𝜉𝑞delimited-[]𝑓𝑤𝜉F(w;q):=\mathbb{E}_{\xi\sim q}[f(w;\xi)]\,,

where f:ℝd×𝒵→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑑𝒵ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathcal{Z}\to\mathbb{R} is given. We use Fk​(w):=F​(w;qk)assignsubscript𝐹𝑘𝑤𝐹𝑤subscript𝑞𝑘F_{k}(w):=F(w;q_{k}) to denote the loss on training device k𝑘k.

We are interested in supervised machine learning, where ξ∈𝒵𝜉𝒵\xi\in\mathcal{Z} is an input-output pair ξ=(x,y)𝜉𝑥𝑦\xi=(x,y). The function f𝑓f is of the form ℓ​(y,φ​(x;w))ℓ𝑦𝜑𝑥𝑤\ell(y,\varphi(x;w)), where φ​(x;w)𝜑𝑥𝑤\varphi(x;w) makes a prediction on input x𝑥x under model w𝑤w using, e.g., a neural network, and ℓℓ\ell is a loss function such as the logistic loss. The weight αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k} is set proportional to the amount of data on device k𝑘k.

Test Devices and Conformity.

In this work, we consider “test” devices, unseen during training, whose distribution can be written as a mixture of the training distributions. We define a mixture pπsubscript𝑝𝜋p_{\pi} with weight π∈ΔN−1𝜋superscriptΔ𝑁1\pi\in\Delta^{N-1} as

pπ:=∑k=1Nπk​qk,assignsubscript𝑝𝜋superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝜋𝑘subscript𝑞𝑘\displaystyle p_{\pi}:=\sum_{k=1}^{N}\pi_{k}q_{k}\,,

where ΔN−1superscriptΔ𝑁1\Delta^{N-1} is the probability simplex in ℝNsuperscriptℝ𝑁\mathbb{R}^{N}. Under this notation, the training distribution is pαsubscript𝑝𝛼p_{\alpha}. We now define conformity of a mixture to the training distribution.

Definition 1.

The conformity conf​(pπ)confsubscript𝑝𝜋\mathrm{conf}(p_{\pi}) of a mixture distribution pπsubscript𝑝𝜋p_{\pi} with weight π𝜋\pi to the training distribution pαsubscript𝑝𝛼p_{\alpha} is defined as mink∈[N]⁡αk/πksubscript𝑘delimited-[]𝑁subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝜋𝑘\min_{k\in[N]}\alpha_{k}/\pi_{k}. The conformity of a client device refers to the conformity of its data distribution.

For every mixture pπsubscript𝑝𝜋p_{\pi}, we have that 0<conf​(pπ)≤10confsubscript𝑝𝜋10<\mathrm{conf}(p_{\pi})\leq 1. A mixture distribution pπsubscript𝑝𝜋p_{\pi} with conf​(pπ)=θconfsubscript𝑝𝜋𝜃\mathrm{conf}(p_{\pi})=\theta must satisfy πk≤αk/θsubscript𝜋𝑘subscript𝛼𝑘𝜃\pi_{k}\leq\alpha_{k}/\theta for each k𝑘k. Since ∑kπk=1subscript𝑘subscript𝜋𝑘1\sum_{k}\pi_{k}=1, we also get that πk≥max⁡{0,αk−(1−θ)}subscript𝜋𝑘0subscript𝛼𝑘1𝜃\pi_{k}\geq\max\{0,\alpha_{k}-(1-\theta)\}. We do not directly impose a lower bound on πksubscript𝜋𝑘\pi_{k} because it is not realistic to assume that the distribution on a test device must necessarily contain a component of every training distribution qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k}.

Interpretation.

Assuming that the training devices are a representative sample of the population, every device’s distribution can be well-approximated by a mixture pπsubscript𝑝𝜋p_{\pi} for some π∈ΔN−1𝜋superscriptΔ𝑁1\pi\in\Delta^{N-1}. Then, the conformity of a device is a scalar summary of how close it is to the population. A test device with conformity θ≈1𝜃1\theta\approx 1 closely conforms to the population. Then, a model trained on the population pαsubscript𝑝𝛼p_{\alpha} can be expected to have a high predictive power, and the user experience on such a device is likely good. In contrast, a test device with conformity θ≈0𝜃0\theta\approx 0 would be vastly different from the population pαsubscript𝑝𝛼p_{\alpha}. Here, the predictive power of a model trained on pαsubscript𝑝𝛼p_{\alpha} could be arbitrarily poor.

There is a trade-off between the fitting to the population distribution and supporting non-conforming test devices, i.e., those with distribution pπsubscript𝑝𝜋p_{\pi} for small conf​(pπ)confsubscript𝑝𝜋\mathrm{conf}(p_{\pi}). The conformity level θ𝜃\theta presents a natural way to encapsulate this tradeoff in a scalar parameter. That is, given a conformity θ∈(0,1)𝜃01\theta\in(0,1), we choose to only support test devices with distribution pπsubscript𝑝𝜋p_{\pi} satisfying conf​(pπ)≥θconfsubscript𝑝𝜋𝜃\mathrm{conf}(p_{\pi})\geq\theta.

Quantile and Superquantile.

Before proceeding, we recall that the (1−θ)1𝜃(1-\theta)-superquantile [38] of a real-valued random variable X𝑋X is defined as

SX​(θ):=infη∈ℝ{η+1θ​𝔼​(X−η)+},assignsubscript𝑆𝑋𝜃subscriptinfimum𝜂ℝ𝜂1𝜃𝔼subscript𝑋𝜂S_{X}(\theta):=\inf_{\eta\in\mathbb{R}}\left\{\eta+\frac{1}{\theta}\,\mathbb{E}(X-\eta)_{+}\right\}\,,

where (ρ)+:=max⁡{0,ρ}assignsubscript𝜌0𝜌(\rho)_{+}:=\max\{0,\rho\}. The right hand side is minimized by the corresponding quantile η⋆=QX​(θ)superscript𝜂⋆subscript𝑄𝑋𝜃\eta^{\star}=Q_{X}(\theta),

QX​(θ):=inf{x∈ℝ:ℙ​(X>x)≤θ}.assignsubscript𝑄𝑋𝜃infimumconditional-set𝑥ℝℙ𝑋𝑥𝜃Q_{X}(\theta):=\inf\left\{x\in\mathbb{R}\,:\,\mathbb{P}(X>x)\leq\theta\right\}\,.

When X𝑋X is continuous, the superquantile has the alternate representation SX​(θ)=𝔼​[X​|X>​QX​(θ)]subscript𝑆𝑋𝜃𝔼delimited-[]𝑋ket𝑋subscript𝑄𝑋𝜃S_{X}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}\big{[}X\,\big{|}\,X>Q_{X}(\theta)\big{]}, as the average of X𝑋X above its (1−θ)1𝜃(1-\theta)-quantile. The superquantile is, therefore, a measure of the upper tail of X𝑋X.

3 The ΔΔ\Delta-FL Framework

We now present the ΔΔ\Delta-FL framework to (a) maintain good predictive power on high-conformity devices, and, (b) improve the predictive power on low-conformity devices.

The ΔΔ\Delta-FL framework supplies each test device with a model appropriate to its conformity. In particular, given a discretization {θ1,…,θr}subscript𝜃1…subscript𝜃𝑟\{\theta_{1},\ldots,\theta_{r}\} of (0,1]01(0,1], ΔΔ\Delta-FL maintains r𝑟r models, one for each level θjsubscript𝜃𝑗\theta_{j} of conformity. Owing to privacy restrictions, the local data is not allowed to leave a device, and hence, the conformity of a test device cannot be measured. Instead, we allow each test device to tune their conformity.

In order to train a model for a given level θ𝜃\theta of conformity, we aim to do well on all mixtures pπsubscript𝑝𝜋p_{\pi} with conf​(pπ)≥θconfsubscript𝑝𝜋𝜃\mathrm{conf}(p_{\pi})\geq\theta. Therefore, we consider the optimization problem

minw∈ℝd⁡[Fθ​(w):=maxπ∈𝒫θ⁡F​(w;pπ)],subscript𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑assignsubscript𝐹𝜃𝑤subscript𝜋subscript𝒫𝜃𝐹𝑤subscript𝑝𝜋\displaystyle\min_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left[F_{\theta}(w):=\max_{\pi\in\mathcal{P}_{\theta}}F(w;p_{\pi})\right]\,, (1)

where 𝒫θ:={π:conf​(pπ)≥θ}assignsubscript𝒫𝜃conditional-set𝜋confsubscript𝑝𝜋𝜃\mathcal{P}_{\theta}:=\{\pi\,:\,\mathrm{conf}(p_{\pi})\geq\theta\}. Equivalently, we have,

𝒫θ={π∈ΔN−1:πk≤αkθ​∀k∈[N]}.subscript𝒫𝜃conditional-set𝜋superscriptΔ𝑁1subscript𝜋𝑘subscript𝛼𝑘𝜃for-all𝑘delimited-[]𝑁\mathcal{P}_{\theta}=\left\{\pi\in\Delta^{N-1}\,:\,\pi_{k}\leq\frac{\alpha_{k}}{\theta}\,\,\forall\,k\in[N]\right\}\,.

First, we formalize the duality of Fθsubscript𝐹𝜃F_{\theta} as a superquantile.

Property 2.

We have Fθ​(w)=minη∈ℝ⁡F¯θ​(w,η)subscript𝐹𝜃𝑤subscript𝜂ℝsubscript¯𝐹𝜃𝑤𝜂F_{\theta}(w)=\min_{\eta\in\mathbb{R}}\overline{F}_{\theta}(w,\eta), for any θ∈(0,1)𝜃01\theta\in(0,1), where F¯θ:ℝd×ℝ→ℝ:subscript¯𝐹𝜃→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝℝ\overline{F}_{\theta}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} is given by

F¯θ​(w,η):=η+1θ​∑k=1Nαk​(Fk​(w)−η)+.assignsubscript¯𝐹𝜃𝑤𝜂𝜂1𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝛼𝑘subscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘𝑤𝜂\displaystyle\overline{F}_{\theta}(w,\eta):=\eta+\frac{1}{\theta}\sum_{k=1}^{N}\alpha_{k}\big{(}F_{k}(w)-\eta\big{)}_{+}\,. (2)

The optimal η𝜂\eta above is the (1−θ)1𝜃(1-\theta)-weighted quantile of Fk​(w)subscript𝐹𝑘𝑤F_{k}(w) with weight αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k} for k=1,…,N𝑘1…𝑁k=1,\ldots,N. The next property shows that the superquantile preserves convexity.

Property 3.

If each Fksubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k} is convex, then for any θ∈(0,1)𝜃01\theta\in(0,1), (a) F¯θsubscript¯𝐹𝜃\overline{F}_{\theta} is convex on ℝd×ℝsuperscriptℝ𝑑ℝ\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathbb{R}, and, (b) Fθsubscript𝐹𝜃F_{\theta} is convex on ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Motivated by these observations, we consider in lieu of (1):

minw∈ℝd,η∈ℝ⁡F¯θ​(w,η).subscriptformulae-sequence𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑𝜂ℝsubscript¯𝐹𝜃𝑤𝜂\displaystyle\min_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d},\eta\in\mathbb{R}}\overline{F}_{\theta}(w,\eta)\,. (3)
Illustration.

We now illustrate the objective on a simple example of a mixture of Gaussians. Consider a mixture of N=3𝑁3N=3 Gaussian distributions in ℝ2superscriptℝ2\mathbb{R}^{2}, with uniform weights (αk=1/Nsubscript𝛼𝑘1𝑁\alpha_{k}=1/N), identity covariance and respective means μ1,μ2,μ3subscript𝜇1subscript𝜇2subscript𝜇3\mu_{1},\mu_{2},\mu_{3} which form a scalene triangle – see Figure 3. We assume that each distribution represents a training device.

Consider the task of mean estimation where f​(w;ξ)=‖ξ−w‖2𝑓𝑤𝜉superscriptnorm𝜉𝑤2f(w;\xi)=\|\xi-w\|^{2} so that F​(w;p)𝐹𝑤𝑝F(w;p) is minimized by the mean of p𝑝p. Suppose in our toy federated learning scenario that a model w𝑤w trained on the 3 available training devices and is deployed on a test device with distribution pπsubscript𝑝𝜋p_{\pi}.

Vanilla federated learning, which is a special case of the ΔΔ\Delta-FL framework with conformity θ=1𝜃1\theta=1, aims to minimize F​(⋅;pα)𝐹⋅subscript𝑝𝛼F(\cdot\,;p_{\alpha}) over the training distribution pαsubscript𝑝𝛼p_{\alpha}. The minimizer w1subscript𝑤1w_{1} of the loss F​(⋅;pα)𝐹⋅subscript𝑝𝛼F(\cdot\,;p_{\alpha}) on the training distribution is simply the mean w1:=(μ1+μ2+μ3)/3assignsubscript𝑤1subscript𝜇1subscript𝜇2subscript𝜇33w_{1}:=(\mu_{1}+\mu_{2}+\mu_{3})/3.

Now consider a conformity level of θ=2/3𝜃23\theta=2/3. In this case, a simple calculation shows that the ΔΔ\Delta-FL objective is a piecewise quadratic, which is minimized at the midpoint of the longest side of the triangle formed by μ1,μ2,μ3subscript𝜇1subscript𝜇2subscript𝜇3\mu_{1},\mu_{2},\mu_{3}. In the example of Figure 3, this is w2/3=(μ1+μ3)/2subscript𝑤23subscript𝜇1subscript𝜇32w_{2/3}=(\mu_{1}+\mu_{3})/2.

Next, consider the set 𝒫2/3subscript𝒫23\mathcal{P}_{2/3} of all mixture weights π𝜋\pi such that conf​(pπ)≥2/3confsubscript𝑝𝜋23\mathrm{conf}(p_{\pi})\geq 2/3. We see from Figure 3 (middle) that there are mixtures for which w2/3subscript𝑤23w_{2/3} is better than w1subscript𝑤1w_{1} and vice-versa. However, from the histogram of losses in Figure 3, we see that the worst loss F​(⋅;pπ)𝐹⋅subscript𝑝𝜋F(\cdot\,;p_{\pi}) over all such mixtures is lower for the ΔΔ\Delta-FL model w2/3subscript𝑤23w_{2/3}. In practical terms, ΔΔ\Delta-FL presents an improvement on devices with the worst user experience. Moreover, by optimizing the superquantile, ΔΔ\Delta-FL aims for good performance on all test devices with a given conformity, irrespective of their distribution. Note that while we use a uniform distribution in the illustration of Figure 3 (right), this distribution is unknown in practice.

4 Algorithms and Convergence

We consider optimization algorithms to solve Problem (3) for a fixed conformity level θ𝜃\theta. We start with a meta-algorithm based on the technique of alternating minimization and then present a concrete implementation of it adapted to the engineering constraints of the federated setting.

Meta-Algorithm.

We start by assuming that all devices participate at all times. An inexact alternating minimization meta-algorithm is given in Algorithm 1. It alternates updates of w𝑤w and η𝜂\eta, where the η𝜂\eta-step can be performed in closed form. For the w𝑤w-step, we consider for some εt>0subscript𝜀𝑡0\varepsilon_{t}>0 the inexactness criterion222 We use σ​(wt)𝜎subscript𝑤𝑡\sigma(w_{t}) to denote the sigma field generated by wtsubscript𝑤𝑡w_{t}.

𝔼​[F¯​(wt+1,ηt)|σ​(wt)]−minw⁡F¯​(w,ηt)≤εt.𝔼delimited-[]conditional¯𝐹subscript𝑤𝑡1subscript𝜂𝑡𝜎subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝑤¯𝐹𝑤subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝜀𝑡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\overline{F}(w_{t+1},\eta_{t})|\sigma(w_{t})\right]-\min_{w}\overline{F}(w,\eta_{t})\leq\varepsilon_{t}\,. (4)

The template in Algorithm 1 can be concretely instantiated with a stochastic optimization algorithm such as SGD to satisfy the inexactness bound.

i.e., gν​(ρ)subscript𝑔𝜈𝜌g_{\nu}(\rho) is a smoothing of (ρ)+subscript𝜌(\rho)_{+}. Fθ,ν​(w):=minη∈ℝ⁡F¯θ,ν​(w,η),assignsubscript𝐹𝜃𝜈𝑤subscript𝜂ℝsubscript¯𝐹𝜃𝜈𝑤𝜂\displaystyle F_{\theta,\nu}(w):=\min_{\eta\in\mathbb{R}}\overline{F}_{\theta,\nu}(w,\eta)\,, (7)

where the minimization over η𝜂\eta can be performed in closed form again. Proposition 4.

Fix θ∈(0,1)𝜃01\theta\in(0,1) and ν=2​δ​θ𝜈2𝛿𝜃\nu=2\delta\theta for some δ>0𝛿0\delta>0. Suppose each Fksubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k} is B𝐵B-Lipshitz and L𝐿L-smooth.     ∇w,ηF¯θ,ν​(wt,ηt)→0→subscript∇𝑤𝜂subscript¯𝐹𝜃𝜈subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡0\nabla_{w,\eta}\overline{F}_{\theta,\nu}(w_{t},\eta_{t})\to 0,  and,

  2. (b)

    dist(0,∂Fθ,ν​(wt))→0→dist0subscript𝐹𝜃𝜈subscript𝑤𝑡0\operatorname*{dist}(0,\partial F_{\theta,\nu}(w_{t}))\to 0.

Furthermore, if each Fksubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k} is convex, then almost surely,

  1. (c)

    Fθ,ν​(wt)→min⁡Fθ,ν→subscript𝐹𝜃𝜈subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝐹𝜃𝜈F_{\theta,\nu}(w_{t})\to\min F_{\theta,\nu},  and,

  2. (d)

    lim supt→∞Fθ​(wt)≤min⁡Fθ+δsubscriptlimit-supremum→𝑡subscript𝐹𝜃subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝐹𝜃𝛿\limsup_{t\to\infty}F_{\theta}(w_{t})\leq\min F_{\theta}+\delta.

The proof is given in Appendix B. The proofs of parts (a), (c) and (d) are elementary, while part (b) is more technical.

Practical Implementation.

To obtain a practical algorithm, we modify, without proof, Algorithm 1 to respect system-level constraints of federated learning at scale.

Firstly, we estimate the η𝜂\eta-step of Algorithm 1 from a sample of devices. This is because devices are unavailable when offline, and device availability typically follows a diurnal pattern. Difficulties caused by the bias of quantile estimators makes the analysis of this scheme beyond this work.

Secondly, we execute the w𝑤w-step as a single round of FedAvg. Communication is often the bottleneck in the federated setting, while local computation is relatively cheap. This heuristic allows us to make more progress at a lower communication cost than strictly following Proposition 4, i.e, solving the w𝑤w-step with decreasing suboptimality.

Lastly, we perform the η𝜂\eta-step and the w𝑤w-step using the same sample of devices. With these modifications in place, the resulting algorithm is given in Algorithm 2. As illustrated in Figure 2, Algorithm 2 may be viewed as an augmentation of FedAvg with an additional step of filtering devices (Line 8). In particular, the aggregation of model parameters can be performed using secure aggregation.

As secure aggregation dominates the running time in the federated setting due to its expensive communication, Algorithm 2 has the same per-iteration complexity as FedAvg.

Privacy.

Algorithm 2 reveals neither the data nor the model parameters of the client devices, the latter via the use of secure aggregation. However, the algorithm, as it is currently stated, requires each selected client devices to reveal its loss (a scalar) on the current model to the server. Appendix B.1 presents a variant of Algorithm 2 which ensures the same privacy-preservation of FedAvg at the cost of extra communication. This is achieved by implementing the quantile calculation using multiple secure aggregation calls.

5 Numerical Simulations

We now experimentally compare the performance of ΔΔ\Delta-FL with FedAvg. The simulations were implemented in Python using automatic differentiation provided by PyTorch, while the data was preprocessed using LEAF [8]. Full details of the simulations are given in Appendix C. A software package implementing the proposed algorithm and scripts to reproduce experimental results can be found in [1].

Datasets, Tasks and Models.

We consider three tasks, whose datasets and numbers of train and test devices are described in Table 1. We weigh training device k𝑘k by the number of datapoints on the device. All models were trained with the (multinomial, if applicable) logistic loss and evaluated with the misclassification error.

  1. (a)

    Character Recognition: We use the EMNIST dataset [11], where the input x𝑥x is a 28×28282828\times 28 grayscale image of a handwritten character and the output y𝑦y is its identification (0-9, a-z, A-Z). Each device is a writer of the character x𝑥x. We use a linear model and a convolutional neural network (ConvNet).

  2. (b)

    Sentiment Analysis: We learn a binary classifier over the Sent140 dataset [16] where the input x𝑥x is a Twitter post and the output y=±1𝑦plus-or-minus1y=\pm 1 is its sentiment. Each device corresponds to a distinct Twitter user. The linear model is built on the average of the GloVe embeddings [34] of the words of the post, while the non-convex model is a Long Short Term Memory model [19] built on the GloVe embeddings. We refer to the latter as “RNN”.

  3. (c)

    Character-Level Language Modeling: We learn a character-level language model over the Complete Works of Shakespeare [43], formulated as a multiclass classification problem, where the input x𝑥x is a window of 20 characters, the output y𝑦y is the next (i.e., 21st) character. Each device is a role from a play (e.g., Brutus from The Tragedy of Julius Caesar). The model is a Gated Recurrent Unit [9], which we refer to as “RNN”.

Hyperparameters and Evaluation Metrics.

Hyperparameters of FedAvg were chosen similar to the defaults of [30]. We fixed an iteration budget for each dataset and tuned a learning rate schedule using grid search to find the best terminal loss averaged over training devices for FedAvg. The same values were used on all ΔΔ\Delta-FL runs without further tuning. In addition, the linear models also use a ℓ22superscriptsubscriptℓ22\ell_{2}^{2} regularization, which was tuned separately for FedAvg and each value of θ𝜃\theta for ΔΔ\Delta-FL. The regularization parameter was selected to minimize the 909090th percentile of the misclassification error on a held-out subset of training devices. Each ΔΔ\Delta-FL experiment was repeated for conformity levels θ=0.8,0.5,0.1𝜃0.80.50.1\theta=0.8,0.5,0.1. Recall that we cannot actually measure the conformity of a test device due to privacy restrictions.

We track the loss F​(⋅;qk)𝐹⋅subscript𝑞𝑘F(\cdot\,;q_{k}) incurred on each training device and the misclassification error on each test device. We summarize these distributions with their mean and the 909090th percentile. We use the latter to gauge performance on devices with low conformity. Other percentiles of these distributions, and more simulation results are presented in Appendix C. We report each metric averaged over 5 different random seeds.

Experimental Results.

Table 2 lists the 909090th percentile of the misclassification error on the test devices on the final model at the end of our iteration budget. We observe that for all datasets, the 909090th percentile of the test error is smaller for ΔΔ\Delta-FL than for FedAvg at some value of θ𝜃\theta, and often at multiple values of θ𝜃\theta. This highlights the benefit of the ΔΔ\Delta-FL framework in dealing with heterogeneous device distributions. Table 3 records the mean of the distribution of test errors. We see that ΔΔ\Delta-FL is on par with FedAvg on the mean of the misclassification errors on the test devices, and sometimes even better.

Performance Across Devices.

We now visualize the misclassification error across all test devices in a histogram in Figure 4. We note that ΔΔ\Delta-FL exhibits thinner upper tails on the error, which shows an improved performance on devices which do not conform with the population.

Next, Figure 5 shows a scatter plot of the loss (resp. error) and the number of datapoints on a training (resp. testing) device. Observe, firstly, that ΔΔ\Delta-FL reduces the variance of of the loss on the train devices. Secondly, note that amongst test devices with a small number of data points (e.g., <200absent200<200 for EMNIST or <100absent100<100 for Sent140), ΔΔ\Delta-FL reduces the variance of the misclassification error. Both effects are more pronounced on the neural network models.

Both these plots are indicative of an improved user experience of ΔΔ\Delta-FL on devices which do not conform as well as devices with little data.

Performance Across Iterations.

Figure 6 compares the convergence of Algorithm 2 with FedAvg, measured in terms of the number of secure aggregation calls. We see that ΔΔ\Delta-FL is competitive with FedAvg in convergence rate, despite using the same hyperparameters which were tuned for FedAvg.

6 Related Work

Federated learning was introduced by McMahan et al. [30] as a distributed learning approach to handle on-device machine learning, with several recent extensions [24, 7, 44, 41, 42, 36] – see [23] for a survey. We address non-conformity of heterogeneous client devices, which is broadly applicable in these settings.

The classical field of distributed optimization [6] has seen a recent surge of interest with frameworks suited to synchronous centralized [45, 29], decentralized [17] and asynchronous settings [26]. Past works [12, 14] have considered model plurality (i.e., an ensemble of global models) in the context of distributed learning.

Robust optimization [5], which espouses hedging against uncertainty by taking a worst-case approach, has become popular in machine learning [27, 13, 25]. This approach is closely related to the risk measure approach studied in economics and finance [2, 38, 4] . The work we present here considers a novel use of the superquantile, a popular risk measure, in handling device heterogeneity in federated learning with a focus on engineering plausibility.

Past works which considered the use of superquantiles in a centralized setting often used linear programming or convex programming approaches including interior point algorithms [40, 37]. In this work, we present a convergent inexact alternate minimization algorithm and show how to practically implement in the case of federated learning.

The paper [31] gave generalization bounds on test distributions which can be expressed as a mixture of training distributions. The technical tools used to address fairness in federated learning in [31, 28] bear a resemblance to ones used here, albeit to address different problems. This connection could however potentially be leveraged to obtain statistical results for our approach. We focus in this paper on the practical optimization aspects of our approach. The orthogonal question of personalization of federated learning models [e.g. 22] is also an interesting avenue for future work.

7 Conclusions

We present a federated learning framework to train models better suited to heterogeneity of client data distributions in general, and non-conforming users in particular. This is achieved by minimizing a parameterized superquantile-based objective with the parameter ranging over conformity levels of the clients. We study an optimization algorithm to minimize this objective and present a practical variant adapted to the engineering constraints of federated learning. We present compelling numerical evidence in support of the proposed framework on linear models and neural networks for various real-world tasks.

Device Heterogeneity in Federated Learning: A Superquantile Approach

Appendix A Problem Setup and Framework

Suppose we have N𝑁N client devices which aim to collaboratively train a machine learning model. We assume that each device k𝑘k is equipped with a probability distribution qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k} over some measurable space 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} (called “data space”) such that the data on device k𝑘k are distributed i.i.d. according to qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k}. Since devices are heterogeneous, we impose no restriction on the similarity of qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k} and qk′subscript𝑞superscript𝑘′q_{k^{\prime}} for k≠k′𝑘superscript𝑘′k\neq k^{\prime}. Further, we assume that each training device k𝑘k is assigned a weight αk>0subscript𝛼𝑘0\alpha_{k}>0, where ∑k=1Nαk=1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝛼𝑘1\sum_{k=1}^{N}\alpha_{k}=1 without loss of generality.

We measure the loss of a model w∈ℝd𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑w\in\mathbb{R}^{d} on a device with data distribution q𝑞q by

F​(w;q)=𝔼ξ∼q​[f​(w;ξ)],𝐹𝑤𝑞subscript𝔼similar-to𝜉𝑞delimited-[]𝑓𝑤𝜉F(w;q)=\mathbb{E}_{\xi\sim q}[f(w;\xi)]\,,

where f:ℝd×𝒵→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑑𝒵ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathcal{Z}\to\mathbb{R} is given. The expectation above is assumed to be well-defined and finite. For a given distribution q𝑞q, smaller values of F​(⋅;q)𝐹⋅𝑞F(\cdot;q) denote a better fit of the model to the data. We use shorthand Fk​(w):=F​(w;qk)assignsubscript𝐹𝑘𝑤𝐹𝑤subscript𝑞𝑘F_{k}(w):=F(w;q_{k}). We assume throughout that each Fksubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k} is bounded from below.

Example.

In the supervised machine learning setting, each ξ∈𝒵𝜉𝒵\xi\in\mathcal{Z} is an input-output pair ξ=(x,y)𝜉𝑥𝑦\xi=(x,y). The function f𝑓f is of the form ℓ​(y,φ​(x;w))ℓ𝑦𝜑𝑥𝑤\ell(y,\varphi(x;w)), where φ​(x;w)𝜑𝑥𝑤\varphi(x;w) makes a prediction on input x𝑥x under model w𝑤w using, for example, a neural network, and ℓℓ\ell is a loss function such as the square loss ℓ​(y,y′)=(y−y′)2/2ℓ𝑦superscript𝑦′superscript𝑦superscript𝑦′22\ell(y,y^{\prime})=(y-y^{\prime})^{2}/2.

Test Devices.

At evaluation time, we get a novel device whose data distribution p′superscript𝑝′p^{\prime} is, owing to heterogeneity of devices, distinct from the training distribution pαsubscript𝑝𝛼p_{\alpha}, which we can write as

pα=∑k=1Nαk​qk.subscript𝑝𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝑞𝑘p_{\alpha}=\sum_{k=1}^{N}\alpha_{k}\,q_{k}\,.

In this work, we investigate methods which perform well not only on average, but also on all devices whose data distribution p′superscript𝑝′p^{\prime} is close to the training distribution pαsubscript𝑝𝛼p_{\alpha}. We shall make this precise in the sequel.

It is known that the standard machine learning technique of minimizing F​(⋅;pα)𝐹⋅subscript𝑝𝛼F(\cdot\,;p_{\alpha}) can lead to bad performance on the test device, even when p′superscript𝑝′p^{\prime} is a small perturbation of the training distribution pαsubscript𝑝𝛼p_{\alpha}.

Approach.

In this work, we focus on test devices whose distribution can be written as a convex combination of the distributions from training devices with weights close to the true training weights αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k}. Concretely, given a conformity level 0<θ<10𝜃10<\theta<1, we define the set 𝒫θsubscript𝒫𝜃\mathcal{P}_{\theta} of permissible weights as

𝒫θ={π∈ΔN−1:πk≤αkθ​∀k∈[N]}.subscript𝒫𝜃conditional-set𝜋superscriptΔ𝑁1subscript𝜋𝑘subscript𝛼𝑘𝜃for-all𝑘delimited-[]𝑁\mathcal{P}_{\theta}=\left\{\pi\in\Delta^{N-1}\,:\,\pi_{k}\leq\frac{\alpha_{k}}{\theta}\,\forall\,k\in[N]\right\}\,.

We now consider distributions of the form

pπ=∑k=1Nπk​qk,subscript𝑝𝜋superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝜋𝑘subscript𝑞𝑘p_{\pi}=\sum_{k=1}^{N}\pi_{k}q_{k}\,,

where π∈𝒫θ𝜋subscript𝒫𝜃\pi\in\mathcal{P}_{\theta}. Note that α=(α1,⋯,αN)∈𝒫θ𝛼subscript𝛼1⋯subscript𝛼𝑁subscript𝒫𝜃\alpha=(\alpha_{1},\cdots,\alpha_{N})\in\mathcal{P}_{\theta} for every θ∈(0,1)𝜃01\theta\in(0,1).

The training approach pursued here consists in minimizing

Fθ​(w):=maxπ∈𝒫θ⁡F​(w;pπ).assignsubscript𝐹𝜃𝑤subscript𝜋subscript𝒫𝜃𝐹𝑤subscript𝑝𝜋\displaystyle F_{\theta}(w):=\max_{\pi\in\mathcal{P}_{\theta}}F(w;p_{\pi})\,. (8)

There is a trade-off between the size of 𝒫θsubscript𝒫𝜃\mathcal{P}_{\theta} and the performance minw⁡F​(w;pα)subscript𝑤𝐹𝑤subscript𝑝𝛼\min_{w}F(w;p_{\alpha}) on the training distribution pαsubscript𝑝𝛼p_{\alpha}. A small conformity θ𝜃\theta implies that we take a more conservative approach where we would like to be able to make guarantees on test distributions pπsubscript𝑝𝜋p_{\pi} which do not conform much with the training distribution pαsubscript𝑝𝛼p_{\alpha}. However, this may come at the cost of fitting the training distribution pαsubscript𝑝𝛼p_{\alpha}.

Duality.

The objective Fθsubscript𝐹𝜃F_{\theta} defined above admits the following dual representation.

Property 5.

For any θ∈(0,1)𝜃01\theta\in(0,1), we have that Fθ​(w)=minη∈ℝ⁡F¯θ​(w,η)subscript𝐹𝜃𝑤subscript𝜂ℝsubscript¯𝐹𝜃𝑤𝜂F_{\theta}(w)=\min_{\eta\in\mathbb{R}}\overline{F}_{\theta}(w,\eta), where F¯θ:ℝd×ℝ→ℝ:subscript¯𝐹𝜃→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝℝ\overline{F}_{\theta}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} is given by

F¯θ​(w,η):=η+1θ​∑k=1Nαk​(Fk​(w)−η)+,assignsubscript¯𝐹𝜃𝑤𝜂𝜂1𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝛼𝑘subscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘𝑤𝜂\overline{F}_{\theta}(w,\eta):=\eta+\frac{1}{\theta}\sum_{k=1}^{N}\alpha_{k}\big{(}F_{k}(w)-\eta\big{)}_{+}\,,

where x∈ℝN𝑥superscriptℝ𝑁x\in\mathbb{R}^{N} and 0<θ<10𝜃10<\theta<1 are fixed. Since the constraint set 𝒫θsubscript𝒫𝜃\mathcal{P}_{\theta} is compact, the objective is bounded, and strong duality holds. The maximum of the linear program above thus equals minη∈ℝ,μ∈ℝ+N⁡D​(η,μ)subscriptformulae-sequence𝜂ℝ𝜇subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑁𝐷𝜂𝜇\min_{\eta\in\mathbb{R},\mu\in\mathbb{R}^{N}_{+}}D(\eta,\mu), where,

Note that F¯θ,νsubscript¯𝐹𝜃𝜈\overline{F}_{\theta,\nu} is bounded from below since each Fksubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k} is bounded from below. This alternate representation is useful because (a) F¯θsubscript¯𝐹𝜃\overline{F}_{\theta} is jointly convex in its arguments whenever f𝑓f is convex in w𝑤w, and (b) Fθsubscript𝐹𝜃F_{\theta} can be recovered from F¯θsubscript¯𝐹𝜃\overline{F}_{\theta} by finding a (weighted) quantile of {Fk​(w)}k=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘𝑤𝑘1𝑁\{F_{k}(w)\}_{k=1}^{N}.

Property 6.

A.1 Smoothing

The function F¯θsubscript¯𝐹𝜃\overline{F}_{\theta} is not smooth owing to the non-smoothness of (ρ)+subscript𝜌(\rho)_{+}. To show convergence, we consider the smoothing F¯θ,ν:ℝd×ℝ→ℝ:subscript¯𝐹𝜃𝜈→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝℝ\overline{F}_{\theta,\nu}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} of F¯θsubscript¯𝐹𝜃\overline{F}_{\theta} defined for ν>0𝜈0\nu>0 as

F¯θ,ν​(w,η):=η+1θ​∑k=1Nαk​gν​(Fk​(w)−η),assignsubscript¯𝐹𝜃𝜈𝑤𝜂𝜂1𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝑔𝜈subscript𝐹𝑘𝑤𝜂\displaystyle\overline{F}_{\theta,\nu}(w,\eta):=\eta+\frac{1}{\theta}\sum_{k=1}^{N}\alpha_{k}g_{\nu}\big{(}F_{k}(w)-\eta\big{)}\,, (9)

where gν:ℝ→ℝ:subscript𝑔𝜈→ℝℝg_{\nu}:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} is a smoothing of (ρ)+=maxγ∈[0,1]⁡{ρ​γ}subscript𝜌subscript𝛾01𝜌𝛾(\rho)_{+}=\max_{\gamma\in[0,1]}\{\rho\gamma\} defined as

gν​(ρ):=maxγ∈[0,1]⁡{ρ​γ−ν​γ22}+ν2={ν/2, if ​ρ≤0,ρ2/(2​ν)+ν/2, if ​0<ρ≤ν,ρ, if ​ρ>ν.assignsubscript𝑔𝜈𝜌subscript𝛾01𝜌𝛾𝜈superscript𝛾22𝜈2cases𝜈2 if 𝜌0superscript𝜌22𝜈𝜈2 if 0𝜌𝜈𝜌 if 𝜌𝜈\displaystyle g_{\nu}(\rho):=\max_{\gamma\in[0,1]}\left\{\rho\gamma-\frac{\nu\gamma^{2}}{2}\right\}+\frac{\nu}{2}=\begin{cases}\nu/2\,,&\text{ if }\rho\leq 0\,,\\ \rho^{2}/(2\nu)+\nu/2\,,&\text{ if }0<\rho\leq\nu\,,\\ \rho\,,&\text{ if }\rho>\nu\,.\end{cases} (10)

It is known (see, e.g., Section D.2) that gνsubscript𝑔𝜈g_{\nu} is 111-Lipschitz, (1/ν)1𝜈(1/\nu)-smooth and that is uniformly approximates g𝑔g to ν/2𝜈2\nu/2, i.e.,

Fθ,ν​(w):=minη∈ℝ⁡F¯θ,ν​(w,η).assignsubscript𝐹𝜃𝜈𝑤subscript𝜂ℝsubscript¯𝐹𝜃𝜈𝑤𝜂\displaystyle F_{\theta,\nu}(w):=\min_{\eta\in\mathbb{R}}\overline{F}_{\theta,\nu}(w,\eta)\,. (11)

When each Fksubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k} is convex, note that (w,η)↦Fk​(w)−ηmaps-to𝑤𝜂subscript𝐹𝑘𝑤𝜂(w,\eta)\mapsto F_{k}(w)-\eta is convex. It follows that (w,η)↦gν​(Fk​(w)−η)maps-to𝑤𝜂subscript𝑔𝜈subscript𝐹𝑘𝑤𝜂(w,\eta)\mapsto g_{\nu}(F_{k}(w)-\eta) is, as the maximum of a family of convex functions, also convex. Therefore, F¯θ,νsubscript¯𝐹𝜃𝜈\overline{F}_{\theta,\nu} is convex since it is the sum of convex functions. ∎

Next, we note that minimization over η∈ℝ𝜂ℝ\eta\in\mathbb{R} in (11) can be performed exactly in closed form.

Property 9.

Let {αk}k∈[N]subscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑘delimited-[]𝑁\{\alpha_{k}\}_{k\in[N]} be strictly positive and sum to 111, ν>0𝜈0\nu>0,and x∈ℝN𝑥superscriptℝ𝑁x\in\mathbb{R}^{N} be given. Then, the minimizers of the function

∎

Finally, we state the following technical lemma, which establishes the property of uniform level-boundedness (defined in the statement of the lemma; see also [39, Definition 1.16]). This will be needed for the proof of Corollary 14.

Lemma 10.

Fix θ∈(0,1)𝜃01\theta\in(0,1) and ν>0𝜈0\nu>0. Consider F¯θ,νsubscript¯𝐹𝜃𝜈\overline{F}_{\theta,\nu} defined in (9), where each Fksubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k} is continuous. That is, for every w^∈ℝd^𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑\widehat{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and λ∈ℝ𝜆ℝ\lambda\in\mathbb{R}, there exists some ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0 such that the set

Sw^,λ:={(w,η)∈ℝd×ℝ:‖w−w^‖≤ρ,F¯θ,ν​(w,η)≤λ}assignsubscript𝑆^𝑤𝜆conditional-set𝑤𝜂superscriptℝ𝑑ℝformulae-sequencenorm𝑤^𝑤𝜌subscript¯𝐹𝜃𝜈𝑤𝜂𝜆S_{\widehat{w},\lambda}:=\left\{(w,\eta)\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathbb{R}\,:\,\|w-\widehat{w}\|\leq\rho\,,\,\overline{F}_{\theta,\nu}(w,\eta)\leq\lambda\right\}

is bounded.

    Fix a w^∈ℝd,λ>0formulae-sequence^𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑𝜆0\widehat{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},\lambda>0. Also, fix a δ>0𝛿0\delta>0 and let ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0 be such that

    maxk∈[N]⁡|Fk​(w)−Fk​(w^)|≤δsubscript𝑘delimited-[]𝑁subscript𝐹𝑘𝑤subscript𝐹𝑘^𝑤𝛿\max_{k\in[N]}|F_{k}(w)-F_{k}(\widehat{w})|\leq\delta

    for all w∈Bρ:={w:‖w−w^‖≤ρ}𝑤subscript𝐵𝜌assignconditional-set𝑤norm𝑤^𝑤𝜌w\in B_{\rho}:=\{w\,:\,\|w-\widehat{w}\|\leq\rho\}, the ball of radius ρ𝜌\rho around w^^𝑤\widehat{w}. This follows from the continuity of Fksubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k}’s.

    mink⁡Fk​(w)−ν≤η^w≤maxk⁡Fk​(w),subscript𝑘subscript𝐹𝑘𝑤𝜈subscript^𝜂𝑤subscript𝑘subscript𝐹𝑘𝑤\min_{k}F_{k}(w)-\nu\leq\widehat{\eta}_{w}\leq\max_{k}F_{k}(w)\,,

Appendix B Algorithm: Convergence Proofs and Full Details

Here, we give the convergence proofs of the results stated in the main text. The proof of Proposition 4 is given as follows: Part (a) in Proposition 11, Part (b) in Corollary 14 and, Parts (c)-(d) in Corollary 12. The proofs of Proposition 11 and Corollary 12 are elementary while the proof of Corollary 14 requires some technical lemmas.

Setup.

We first recall the setup. Following Properties 5 and 6, consider the following minimization problem in place of (8):

min(w,η)∈ℝd×ℝ⁡F¯θ​(w,η).subscript𝑤𝜂superscriptℝ𝑑ℝsubscript¯𝐹𝜃𝑤𝜂\displaystyle\min_{(w,\eta)\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathbb{R}}\overline{F}_{\theta}(w,\eta)\,. (12)

Since this problem is nonsmooth, we fix some ν>0𝜈0\nu>0, and consider the following smooth surrogate

min(w,η)∈ℝd×ℝ⁡F¯θ,ν​(w,η).subscript𝑤𝜂superscriptℝ𝑑ℝsubscript¯𝐹𝜃𝜈𝑤𝜂\displaystyle\min_{(w,\eta)\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathbb{R}}\overline{F}_{\theta,\nu}(w,\eta)\,. (13)
Algorithm.

Recall that the template alternating minimization procedure (from Algorithm 1) to solve Problem (13) is to start with some w0∈ℝdsubscript𝑤0superscriptℝ𝑑w_{0}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and iterate as

ηt∈arg​minη∈ℝ⁡F¯θ,ν​(wt,η)wt+1≈arg​minw∈ℝd⁡F¯θ,ν​(w,ηt).subscript𝜂𝑡absentsubscriptargmin𝜂ℝsubscript¯𝐹𝜃𝜈subscript𝑤𝑡𝜂subscript𝑤𝑡1absentsubscriptargmin𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑subscript¯𝐹𝜃𝜈𝑤subscript𝜂𝑡\displaystyle\begin{aligned} \eta_{t}&\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\eta\in\mathbb{R}}\overline{F}_{\theta,\nu}(w_{t},\eta)\\ w_{t+1}&\approx\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\overline{F}_{\theta,\nu}(w,\eta_{t})\,.\end{aligned} (14)

Due to Property 9, the η𝜂\eta-step can be computed exactly in closed form by simply sorting {Fk​(wt)}k∈[N]subscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝑤𝑡𝑘delimited-[]𝑁\{F_{k}(w_{t})\}_{k\in[N]} obtained from each of the devices. For the inexact w𝑤w-step, we assume that the random variable wt+1subscript𝑤𝑡1w_{t+1} satisfies

Convergence Results.

Then, we can show almost sure convergence of (14) to a stationary point of F¯θ,νsubscript¯𝐹𝜃𝜈\overline{F}_{\theta,\nu} provided that the inexactness εt=o​(t−1)subscript𝜀𝑡𝑜superscript𝑡1\varepsilon_{t}=o(t^{-1}), e.g., εt=t−(1+δ)subscript𝜀𝑡superscript𝑡1𝛿\varepsilon_{t}=t^{-(1+\delta)} for some δ>0𝛿0\delta>0. Note that this proof does not require convexity.

Next, we sharpen the convergence result in the presence of convexity.

In order to show the result on the subdifferential, we first need the following technical lemma. The notation ∂\partial refers to the Clarke subdifferential — see Appendix D.1 for details.

Lemma 13.

Consider the setting of Proposition 11. The function Fθ,νsubscript𝐹𝜃𝜈F_{\theta,\nu} is locally Lipschitz and differentiable almost everywhere. Furthermore, Fθ,νsubscript𝐹𝜃𝜈F_{\theta,\nu} is differentiable at w𝑤w precisely when

Yθ,ν​(w):={∇wF¯θ,ν​(w,η)​ for all ​η∈arg​minη′∈ℝ⁡F¯​(w,η′)}assignsubscript𝑌𝜃𝜈𝑤subscript∇𝑤subscript¯𝐹𝜃𝜈𝑤𝜂 for all 𝜂subscriptargminsuperscript𝜂′ℝ¯𝐹𝑤superscript𝜂′Y_{\theta,\nu}(w):=\left\{\nabla_{w}\overline{F}_{\theta,\nu}(w,\eta)\text{ for all }\eta\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\eta^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}}\overline{F}(w,\eta^{\prime})\right\}

is reduced to a singleton. In this case, we have Yθ,ν​(w)={∇Fθ,ν​(w)}subscript𝑌𝜃𝜈𝑤∇subscript𝐹𝜃𝜈𝑤Y_{\theta,\nu}(w)=\{\nabla F_{\theta,\nu}(w)\}. In general, we have ∂Fθ,ν​(w)=convYθ,ν​(w)subscript𝐹𝜃𝜈𝑤convsubscript𝑌𝜃𝜈𝑤{\partial}F_{\theta,\nu}(w)=\operatorname*{conv}Y_{\theta,\nu}(w).

Proof.

Recall from the setting of Proposition 11 that each Fksubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k} is continuously differentiable. The result is essentially a consequence of [39, Theorem 10.58], but we need to invoke several other results of [39], as follows. Proposition 9.10 gives that Fθ,νsubscript𝐹𝜃𝜈F_{\theta,\nu} is locally Lipschitz (or strictly continuous in the terminology of the book). Theorems 8.49 and 9.13(b) then give that the Clarke subdifferential is the convex hull of the limiting subdifferential (which is closed and bounded). Finally, with the help of Lemma 10, we can apply Theorem 10.58, to get the expressions of the limiting subdifferential with Yθ,ν​(w)subscript𝑌𝜃𝜈𝑤Y_{\theta,\nu}(w), and the characterization of differentiability. Thus, we get the expressions of the statement and the proof is complete. Note that in the convex case, we retrieve the result of [18, Corollary 4.5.3]. ∎

This property gives the following subdifferential result as a corollary of Proposition 11.

Corollary 14.

Consider the setting of Proposition 11. We have convergence to stationarity: the distance of the subdifferential to 00, denoted dist(0,∂Fθ,ν​(wt))dist0subscript𝐹𝜃𝜈subscript𝑤𝑡\operatorname*{dist}(0,\partial F_{\theta,\nu}(w_{t})), vanishes almost surely.

Proof.

We can bound the distance of the subdifferential to 00 from the expressions of of Lemma 13, as follows:

dist(0,∂Fθ,ν​(wt))dist0subscript𝐹𝜃𝜈subscript𝑤𝑡\displaystyle\operatorname*{dist}(0,\partial F_{\theta,\nu}(w_{t})) =dist(0,convYθ,ν​(wt))≤dist(0,Yθ,ν​(wt))absentdist0convsubscript𝑌𝜃𝜈subscript𝑤𝑡dist0subscript𝑌𝜃𝜈subscript𝑤𝑡\displaystyle=\operatorname*{dist}(0,\operatorname*{conv}Y_{\theta,\nu}(w_{t}))\leq\operatorname*{dist}(0,Y_{\theta,\nu}(w_{t}))
=minη​ optimal⁡‖∇wF¯θ,ν​(wt,η)‖≤‖∇wF¯θ,ν​(wt,ηt)‖.absentsubscript𝜂 optimalnormsubscript∇𝑤subscript¯𝐹𝜃𝜈subscript𝑤𝑡𝜂normsubscript∇𝑤subscript¯𝐹𝜃𝜈subscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡\displaystyle=\min_{\eta\text{ optimal}}\|\nabla_{w}\overline{F}_{\theta,\nu}(w_{t},\eta)\|\leq\|\nabla_{w}\overline{F}_{\theta,\nu}(w_{t},\eta_{t})\|\,.

The asymptotic stationarity is thus a direct consequence of Proposition 11. ∎

B.1 Quantile Computation with Secure Aggregation

Recall from the Section 4 that Algorithm 2, as stated, requires each selected client device to send its loss to the server for the client filtering step. We now present a way to perform this step without any reduction in privacy from directly sending client losses to the server. This can be achieved by implementing the quantile computation using secure aggregation. This section is based on [36], who show how to compute the geometric median using secure aggregation.

Setup.

Suppose we wish to find the τ𝜏\tau-quantile of x1,⋯,xm∈ℝsubscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑥𝑚ℝx_{1},\cdots,x_{m}\in\mathbb{R} with respective weights α1,⋯,αm>0subscript𝛼1⋯subscript𝛼𝑚0\alpha_{1},\cdots,\alpha_{m}>0. Recall that μτsubscript𝜇𝜏\mu_{\tau} is the τ𝜏\tau quantile if

∑k:xk≤μταk≥τ,and,​∑k:xk≥μταk≥1−τ.formulae-sequencesubscript:𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝜇𝜏subscript𝛼𝑘𝜏and,subscript:𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝜇𝜏subscript𝛼𝑘1𝜏\sum_{k\,:\,x_{k}\leq\mu_{\tau}}\alpha_{k}\geq\tau\,,\quad\text{and,}\quad\sum_{k\,:\,x_{k}\geq\mu_{\tau}}\alpha_{k}\geq 1-\tau\,.

It is known [e.g., 15, Chap. 1, Exercise 3] that μτsubscript𝜇𝜏\mu_{\tau} is a τ𝜏\tau-quantile iff it it minimizes Hτ:ℝ→ℝ:subscript𝐻𝜏→ℝℝH_{\tau}:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} defined as

Hτ​(μ):=∑k=1mαk​hτ​(xk−μ),where,hτ​(ρ):={τ​ρ, if ​ρ≥0,−(1−τ)​ρ, if ​ρ<0.formulae-sequenceassignsubscript𝐻𝜏𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑚subscript𝛼𝑘subscriptℎ𝜏subscript𝑥𝑘𝜇whereassignsubscriptℎ𝜏𝜌cases𝜏𝜌 if 𝜌01𝜏𝜌 if 𝜌0H_{\tau}(\mu):=\sum_{k=1}^{m}\alpha_{k}h_{\tau}(x_{k}-\mu)\,,\quad\text{where},\quad h_{\tau}(\rho):=\begin{cases}\tau\rho\,,&\text{ if }\rho\geq 0\,,\\ -(1-\tau)\rho\,,&\text{ if }\rho<0\,.\end{cases}
Algorithm.

Recall that secure aggregation can find a weighted mean of vectors (and hence, scalars) distributed across m𝑚m devices without revealing each device’s vector to other devices or the server. We now show how to compute a quantile as an iterative weighted mean, making it amenable to implementation via secure aggregation. We note that this might not be the most efficient way of implementing quantile computation in a privacy-preserving manner. This is because secure aggregation was designed for high-dimensional vectors and it might be possible to do much better in the case of scalars. Nevertheless, we present the algorithm as a proof-of-concept. The underlying algorithm, based on the principle of majorization-minimization was used, e.g.,in [21].

For any μ~∉{x1,⋯,xm}~𝜇subscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑥𝑚\widetilde{\mu}\notin\{x_{1},\cdots,x_{m}\} , define

H~τ​(μ;μ~):=14​∑k=1mαk​[‖xk−μ‖2‖xk−μ~‖+(4​τ−2)​(xk−μ)+‖xk−μ~‖],assignsubscript~𝐻𝜏𝜇~𝜇14superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑚subscript𝛼𝑘delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript𝑥𝑘𝜇2normsubscript𝑥𝑘~𝜇4𝜏2subscript𝑥𝑘𝜇normsubscript𝑥𝑘~𝜇\widetilde{H}_{\tau}(\mu;\widetilde{\mu}):=\frac{1}{4}\sum_{k=1}^{m}\alpha_{k}\left[\frac{\|x_{k}-\mu\|^{2}}{\|x_{k}-\widetilde{\mu}\|}+(4\tau-2)(x_{k}-\mu)+\|x_{k}-\widetilde{\mu}\|\right]\,,

as a majorizing surrogate for Hτsubscript𝐻𝜏H_{\tau} at μ~~𝜇\widetilde{\mu}, i.e., H~τ​(⋅;μ~)≥Hτsubscript~𝐻𝜏⋅~𝜇subscript𝐻𝜏\widetilde{H}_{\tau}(\cdot\,;\widetilde{\mu})\geq H_{\tau} and H~τ​(μ~;μ~)=Hτ​(μ~)subscript~𝐻𝜏~𝜇~𝜇subscript𝐻𝜏~𝜇\widetilde{H}_{\tau}(\widetilde{\mu};\widetilde{\mu})=H_{\tau}(\widetilde{\mu}). Note that H~τ​(μ;μ~)subscript~𝐻𝜏𝜇~𝜇\widetilde{H}_{\tau}(\mu;\widetilde{\mu}) is an isotropic quadratic in μ𝜇\mu.

where

Modifying ΔΔ\Delta-FL.

We now modify Algorithm 2 to perform the quantile computation in a privacy-preserving manner. However, the server can no longer perform the client filtering step. For this, we pass η𝜂\eta to the clients and let them filter themselves in the run of LocalUpdate. The overall algorithm in given in Algorithm 3.

Appendix C Experimental Results: Complete Details

We conduct our experiments on three datasets from computer vision and natural language processing. These datasets contain a natural, non-iid split of data which is reflective of data heterogeneity encountered in federated learning. In this section, we describe in details the experimental setup and the results. Section C.1 described the datasets and tasks. Section C.2 gives a detailed description of the hyperparameters used and the evaluation methodology. Lastly, Section C.3 gives the experimental results.

Since each device has a finite number of datapoints in the examples below, we let its probability distribution qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k} to be the empirical distribution over the available examples, and the weight αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k} to be proportional to the number of datapoints available on the device.

C.1 Datasets and Tasks

We use the three following datasets, described in detail below. The data was preprocessed using the LEAF framework [8].

C.1.1 EMNIST for handwritten-letter recognition

Dataset.

EMNIST [11] is a character recognition dataset. This dataset contains images of handwritten digits or letters, labeled with their identification (a-z,A-Z, 0-9). The images are grey-scaled pictures of 28×28=784282878428\times 28=784 pixels.

Train and Test Devices.

Each image is also annotated with the “writer” of the image, i.e., the human subject who hand-wrote the digit/letter during the data collection process. From this set of devices, we discard all devices containing less than 100 images and randomly subsampled half of the remaining devices resulting in 173017301730 total devices. We performed the subsampling for computational tractability. We finally split these 173017301730 devices into a training set of devices and a testing set of devices of equal sizes.

Model.

We consider the following models for this task.

  • •

    Linear Model: We use a linear softmax regression model. In this case each Fksubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k} is convex. We train parameters w∈ℝ62×784𝑤superscriptℝ62784w\in\mathbb{R}^{62\times 784}. Given an input image x∈ℝ784𝑥superscriptℝ784x\in\mathbb{R}^{784}, the score of each class c∈[62]𝑐delimited-[]62c\in[62] is the dot product ⟨wc,x⟩subscript𝑤𝑐𝑥\langle w_{c},x\rangle. The probability pcsubscript𝑝𝑐p_{c} assigned to each class is then computed as a softmax: pc=exp⁡⟨wc,x⟩/∑c′exp⁡⟨wc′,x⟩subscript𝑝𝑐subscript𝑤𝑐𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑐′subscript𝑤superscript𝑐′𝑥p_{c}=\exp{\langle w_{c},x\rangle}/\sum_{c^{\prime}}\exp{\langle w_{c^{\prime}},x\rangle}. The prediction for a given image is then the class with the highest probability.

  • •

    ConvNet: We also consider a convolutional neural network. Its architecture satisfies the following scheme:

    Input 784 ⟶⟶ Input 784 absent\displaystyle\parbox{30.0pt}{\centering Input \\ \small{784}\@add@centering}\longrightarrow Conv 2D filter = 32 kernel = ×55 ⟶ReLU⟶ Max Pool kernel = ×22 stride = 2 ⟶ Conv 2D filter = 64 kernel = ×55 \displaystyle\parbox{70.0pt}{\centering Conv 2D \\ \small{filter = 32} \\ \small{kernel = $5\times 5$}\@add@centering}\longrightarrow\;\;\;\;\parbox{30.0pt}{ReLU}\;\;\longrightarrow\parbox{76.0pt}{\centering Max Pool \\ \small{kernel = $2\times 2$} \\ \small{stride = $2$}\@add@centering}\longrightarrow\parbox{76.0pt}{\centering Conv 2D \\ \small{filter = 64} \\ \small{kernel = $5\times 5$}\@add@centering}
    ⟶ReLU⟶ Max Pool kernel = ×22 stride = 2 ⟶ F.C. units = 62 ⟶score⟶absentReLU⟶ Max Pool kernel = ×22 stride = 2 ⟶ F.C. units = 62 ⟶score\displaystyle\longrightarrow\;\;\parbox{30.0pt}{ReLU}\!\!\!\longrightarrow\!\!\!\parbox{76.0pt}{\centering Max Pool \\ \small{kernel = $2\times 2$} \\ \small{stride = $2$}\@add@centering}\longrightarrow\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\parbox{76.0pt}{\centering F.C. \\ \small{units = $62$}\@add@centering}\longrightarrow\text{score}

    In other words, it contains two convolutional layers with max-pooling and one fully connected layer (F.C) of which outputs a vector in ℝ62superscriptℝ62\mathbb{R}^{62}. The outputs of the ConvNet are scores with respect to each class. They are also used with a softmax operation to compute probabilities.

The loss used to train both models is the multinomial logistic loss L​(p,y)=−log⁡py𝐿𝑝𝑦subscript𝑝𝑦L(p,y)=-\log p_{y} where p𝑝p denotes the vector of probabilities computed by the model and pysubscript𝑝𝑦p_{y} denotes its y𝑦yth component. In the convex case we add a quadratic regularization term of the form (λ/2)​‖w‖22𝜆2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑤22({\lambda}/{2})\|w\|_{2}^{2}.

C.1.2 Sent140 for Sentiment Analysis

Dataset.

Sent140 [16] is a text dataset of 1,600,498 tweets produced by 660,120 Twitter accounts. Each tweet is represented by a character string with emojis redacted. Each tweet is labeled with a binary sentiment reaction (i.e., positive or negative), which is inferred based on the emojis in the original tweet.

Train and Test Devices.

Each device represents a twitter account and contains only tweets published by this account. From this set of devices we discarded all devices containing less that 50 tweets, and split the 877 remaining devices rest of devices into a train set and a test set of sizes 438438438 and 439439439 respectively. This split was held fixed for all experiments. Each word in the tweet is encoded by its 505050-dimensional GloVe embedding [34].

Model.

We consider the following models.

  • •

    Linear Model: We consider a l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-regularized linear logistic regression model where the parameter vector w𝑤w is of dimension 505050. In this case, each Fksubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k} is convex. We summarize each tweet by the average of the GloVe embeddings of the words of the tweet.

  • •

    RNN: The nonconvex model is a Long Short Term Memory (LSTM) model [19] built on the GloVe embeddings of the words of the tweet. The hidden dimension of the LSTM is same as the embedding dimension, i.e., 505050. We refer to it as “RNN”.

The loss function is the binary logistic loss.

C.1.3 Shakespeare for Language Modeling

Dataset.

The dataset consists of text from the Complete Works of William Shakespeare as raw text. We formulate the task as a multi-class classification problem with 53 classes (a-z, A-Z, other) as follows. At each point, we consider the previous H=20𝐻20H=20 characters, and build x∈{0,1}H×53𝑥superscript01𝐻53x\in\{0,1\}^{H\times 53} as a one-hot encoding of these H𝐻H characters. The goal is then to predict the next character, which can belong to 53 classes.

Train and Test Devices.

Each device corresponds to a role in a given play (e.g., Brutus from The Tragedy of Julius Caesar). All devices with less than 100 total examples are discarded, and the remaining devices are split into 544544544 training and 545545545 testing devices.

Models.

We use a Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) model [9] with 128128128 hidden units for this purpose. We refer to it as “RNN” in the plots. This is followed by a fully connected layer with 53 outputs, the output of which is used as the score for each character. As in the case of image recognition, probabilities are obtained using the softmax operation. We use the multinomial logistic loss.

C.2 Algorithms, Hyperparameters and Evaluation strategy

C.2.1 Algorithms

We compare FedAvg [30] with the proposed algorithm, given in Algorithm 2 on the datasets presented in Section C.1. We run Algorithm 2 with different conformity levels θ𝜃\theta for θ∈{0.8,0.5,0.1}𝜃0.80.50.1\theta\in\{0.8,0.5,0.1\}.

C.2.2 Hyperparameters

Rounds.

We measure the progress of each algorithm by the number of calls to secure aggregation, i.e., the number of communication rounds. Both FedAvg and Algorithm 2 require one call to secure aggregation per iteration, hence the number of communication rounds is also equivalently the number of iterations of each algorithm.

For the experiments, we choose the number of communication rounds depending on the convergence of the optimization and a budget on wall-clock time. For the EMNIST dataset, we run the algorithm for 300030003000 communication rounds with the linear model and 100010001000 for the ConvNet. For the Sent140 dataset, we run the 100010001000 communication rounds for the linear model and 600600600 for the RNN. For the Shakespeare dataset, we run 600600600 communication rounds.

Devices per Round.

We chose the number of devices per round similar to the baselines of [30]. All devices are assumed to be available and selections are made uniformly at random. In particular, we select 100100100 devices per round for all experiments with the exception of Sent140 RNN for which we used 505050 devices per round.

LocalUpdate and Minibatch Size.

Each selected device (which is not un-selected, in case of Algorithm 2) locally runs 111 epoch of mini-batch stochastic gradient descent in the LocalUpdate method. We used the default mini-batch of 101010 for all experiments [30], except for 161616 for EMNIST ConvNet and Shakespeare. This is because the latter experiments were run using on a GPU, as we describe in the section on the hardware.

Learning rate scheme.

We now describe the learning rate γtsubscript𝛾𝑡\gamma_{t} used during LocalUpdate. For the linear model we used a constant fixed learning rate γt≡γ0subscript𝛾𝑡subscript𝛾0\gamma_{t}\equiv\gamma_{0}, while for the neural network models, we using a step decay scheme of the learning rate γt=γ0​c−⌊t/t0⌋subscript𝛾𝑡subscript𝛾0superscript𝑐𝑡subscript𝑡0\gamma_{t}=\gamma_{0}c^{-\lfloor t/t_{0}\rfloor} for some where γ0subscript𝛾0\gamma_{0} and 0<c≤10𝑐10<c\leq 1 are tuned. We tuned the learning rates only for the baseline FedAvg and used the same learning rate for ΔΔ\Delta-FL at all values of θ𝜃\theta.

For the neural network models, we fixed t0subscript𝑡0t_{0} so that the learning rate was decayed once or twice during the fixed time horizon T𝑇T. In particular, we used t0=400subscript𝑡0400t_{0}=400 for EMNIST ConvNet (where T=1000𝑇1000T=1000), t0=200subscript𝑡0200t_{0}=200 for Sent140 RNN (where T=600𝑇600T=600) and t0=200subscript𝑡0200t_{0}=200 for Shakespeare (where T=600𝑇600T=600). We tuned c𝑐c from the set {2−3,2−2,2−1,1}superscript23superscript22superscript211\{2^{-3},2^{-2},2^{-1},1\}, while the choice of the range of γ0subscript𝛾0\gamma_{0} depended on the dataset-model pair. The tuning criterion we used was the mean of the loss distribution over the training devices (with device k𝑘k weighted by αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k}) at the end of the time horizon. That is, we chose the γ0,csubscript𝛾0𝑐\gamma_{0},c which gave the best terminal training loss.

Tuning of the regularization parameter.

The regularization parameter λ𝜆\lambda for linear models was tuned with cross validation from the set {10−k:k∈{3,⋯,8}}conditional-setsuperscript10𝑘𝑘3⋯8\{10^{-k}\,:\,k\in\{3,\cdots,8\}\}. This was performed as described below.

For each dataset, we held out half the training devices as validation devices. Then, for different values of the regularization parameter, we trained a model with the (smaller subset of) training devices and evaluate its performance on the validation devices. We selected the value of the regularization parameter as the one which gave the smallest 101010th percentile of the misclassification error on the validation devices.

C.2.3 Evaluation Strategy and Other Details

Evaluation metrics.

We record the loss of each training device and the misclassification error of each testing device, as measured on its local data.

The evaluation metrics noted in Section C.3 are the following : the weighted mean of the loss distribution over the training devices, the (unweighted) mean misclassification error over the testing devices, the weighted τ𝜏\tau-percentile of the loss over the training device and the (unweighted) τ𝜏\tau-percentile of the misclassification error over the testing devices for values of τ𝜏\tau among {20,50,60,80,90,95}205060809095\{20,50,60,80,90,95\}. The weight used for training device k𝑘k is αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k}, which was set proportional to the number of datapoints on the device.

Evaluation times.

We evaluate the model during training process for once every l𝑙l rounds. The value of l𝑙l used was l=50𝑙50l=50 for EMNIST linear model, l=10𝑙10l=10 for EMNIST ConvNet and Shakespeare, l=20𝑙20l=20 for Sent140 linear model and l=25𝑙25l=25 for Sent140 RNN.

Hardware.

We run each experiment as a simulation as a single process. The linear models were trained on m5.8xlarge AWS instances, each with an Intel Xeon Platinum 8000 series processor with 128128128 GB of memory running at most 3.13.13.1 GHz. The neural network experiments were trained on workstation with an Intel i9 processor with 128128128 GB of memory at 1.21.21.2 GHz, and two Nvidia Titan Xp GPUs. The Sent140 RNN experiments were run on a CPU while the other neural network experiments were run using GPUs.

Software Packages.

Our implementation is based on NumPy using the Python language. In the neural network experiments, we use PyTorch to implement the LocalUpdate procedure, i.e., the model itself and the automatic differentiation routines provided by PyTorch to make SGD updates.

Randomness.

Since several sampling routines appear in the procedures such as the selection of devices or the local stochastic gradient, we carry our experiments with five different seeds and plot the average metric value over these seeds. Each simulation is run on a single process. Where appropriate, we report one standard deviation from the mean.

C.3 Experimental Results

We now present the experimental results of the paper.

  • •

    We study the performance of each algorithm over the course of the optimization.

  • •

    We plot the histograms the distribution of train losses and test misclassification error over the devices at the end of the training process.

  • •

    We present in the form of scatter plots the training loss and test misclassification error across devices achieved at the end of training, versus the number of local data points on the device.

  • •

    We present the number of devices selected at each communication round for ΔΔ\Delta-FL (after device filtering).

  • •

    We study the effect of implementing the w𝑤w-step as multiple iteration of FedAvg (recall that Algorithm 2 uses one round of FedAvg for the w𝑤w-step of the alternating minimization meta-algorithm of Algorithm 1).

Performance Across Iterations.

We group plots by models and datasets. The x𝑥x axis of the plots below represents the number of communication rounds along the simulation. The y𝑦y-axis represents either the training loss or the testing accuracy (either the mean or some percentile). Table 4 lists the figure numbers with the corresponding plots.

Histograms of Loss and Test Misc. Error over Devices.

Here, we plot the histograms of the loss distribution over training devices and the misclassification error distribution over testing devices. We report the losses and errors obtained at the end of the training process. Each metric is averaged per device over 5 runs of the random seed.

Figure 12 shows the histograms for EMNIST, while Figure 13 shows the histograms for Sent140 and Shakespeare.

We note that ΔΔ\Delta-FL tends to exhibit thinner upper tails at some values of θ𝜃\theta and often at multiple values of θ𝜃\theta. This shows the benefit of using ΔΔ\Delta-FL over vanilla FedAvg.

Performance compared to local data size.

Next, we plot the loss on training devices versus the amount of local data on the device and the misclassification error on the test devices versus the amount of local data on the device. See Figure 14 for EMNIST and Figure 15 for Sent140 and Shakespeare.

Observe, firstly, that ΔΔ\Delta-FL reduces the variance of of the loss on the train devices. Secondly, note that amongst test devices with a small number of data points (e.g., <200absent200<200 for EMNIST or <100absent100<100 for Sent140), ΔΔ\Delta-FL reduces the variance of the misclassification error. Both effects are more pronounced on the neural network models.

Number of Devices Selected per Communication Rounds.

Next, we plot the number of devices selected per round (after device filtering, if applicable). The shaded area denotes the maximum and minimum over 5 random runs. We see from Figure 16 that device-filtering is stable in the number of devices filtered out.

Effect of the Period of Update of η𝜂\eta.

Here, we compare with the experiments to update η𝜂\eta every Tηsubscript𝑇𝜂T_{\eta} rounds. Equivalently, this amounts to running the w𝑤w-step of the alternation minimization meta-algorithm for Tηsubscript𝑇𝜂T_{\eta} steps. See Figure 17 for EMNIST linear model and Figure 18 for Sent140 linear model. We see that on the Sent140 linear model, the choice of Tηsubscript𝑇𝜂T_{\eta} does not make any difference, while for EMNIST, larger Tηsubscript𝑇𝜂T_{\eta} appears to help. Note that Algorithm 2 corresponds to Tη=1subscript𝑇𝜂1T_{\eta}=1.

Appendix D Properties of Subdifferentials and Smoothing

D.1 Subdifferentials of Non-convex Functions

We briefly recall the standard notions of subgradients for nonsmooth functions. We follow the terminology of standard textbooks [10, 39]. For a function φ:ℝd→ℝ∪{+∞}:𝜑→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝ\varphi\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}\cup\{+\infty\}, we define the regular (or Fréchet) subdifferential of φ𝜑\varphi at x¯¯𝑥\bar{x} as

∂Rφ​(x¯)={z∈ℝn:φ​(x)≥φ​(x¯)+z⊤​(x−x¯)+o​(‖x−x¯‖)},superscript𝑅𝜑¯𝑥conditional-set𝑧superscriptℝ𝑛𝜑𝑥𝜑¯𝑥superscript𝑧top𝑥¯𝑥𝑜norm𝑥¯𝑥\partial^{R}\varphi(\bar{x})=\{z\in\mathbb{R}^{n}:~{}\varphi(x)\geq\varphi(\bar{x})+{z}^{\top}(x-\bar{x})+o(\|x-\bar{x}\|)\},

which corresponds to the set of gradients of smooth functions that are below φ𝜑\varphi and coincide with it at x𝑥x. We then introduce the limiting subdifferential as the set of all limits produced by regular subgradients

∂Lφ​(x¯)=lim supx→x¯,φ​(x)→φ​(x¯)∂Rφ​(x).superscript𝐿𝜑¯𝑥subscriptlimit-supremumformulae-sequence→𝑥¯𝑥→𝜑𝑥𝜑¯𝑥superscript𝑅𝜑𝑥\partial^{L}\varphi(\bar{x})=\limsup_{x\rightarrow\bar{x},\varphi(x)\rightarrow\varphi(\bar{x})}\partial^{R}\varphi(x).

We also consider the (Clarke) subdifferential which can be defined, when φ𝜑\varphi is locally Lipschitz, by the convex hull of the limiting subdifferential:

∂φ​(x¯)=conv​∂Lφ​(x¯).𝜑¯𝑥convsuperscript𝐿𝜑¯𝑥\partial\varphi(\bar{x})=\text{conv}\ \partial^{L}\varphi(\bar{x}).

These notions generalize (sub)gradients of both smooth functions and convex functions: for these functions indeed, the three subdifferentials coincide, and they reduce to {∇φ​(x¯)}∇𝜑¯𝑥\{\nabla\varphi(\bar{x})\} when φ𝜑\varphi is smooth and to the standard subdifferential from convex analysis when φ𝜑\varphi is convex.

D.2 Infimal Convolution Smoothing

A convex, non-smooth function hℎh can be smoothed by infimal convolution with a smooth function [32, 3]. We use its dual representation, recalled below.

Definition 15.

For a given convex function h:ℝm→ℝ:ℎ→superscriptℝ𝑚ℝh:\mathbb{R}^{m}\to\mathbb{R}, a smoothing function ω:domh∗→ℝ:𝜔→domsuperscriptℎℝ\omega:\operatorname*{dom}h^{*}\to\mathbb{R} which is 1-strongly convex with respect to ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\|, and a parameter ν>0𝜈0\nu>0, define

hν​ω​(z):=maxu∈domh∗⁡{⟨u,z⟩−h∗​(u)−ν​ω​(u)}.assignsubscriptℎ𝜈𝜔𝑧subscript𝑢domsuperscriptℎ𝑢𝑧superscriptℎ𝑢𝜈𝜔𝑢\displaystyle h_{\nu\omega}(z):=\max_{u\in\operatorname*{dom}h^{*}}\left\{\langle u,z\rangle-h^{*}(u)-\nu\omega(u)\right\}\,.

as the smoothing of hℎh by ν​ω𝜈𝜔\nu\omega.

We now state a classical result showing how the parameter ν𝜈\nu controls both the approximation error and the level of the smoothing. For a proof, see [35, Proposition 39], which is an extension of [3, Theorem 4.1, Lemma 4.2].

Theorem 16.

Consider the setting of Def. 15. The smoothing hν​ωsubscriptℎ𝜈𝜔h_{\nu\omega} is continuously differentiable and its gradient, given by

∇hν​ω​(z)=arg​maxu∈domh∗⁡{⟨u,z⟩−h∗​(u)−ν​ω​(u)}∇subscriptℎ𝜈𝜔𝑧subscriptargmax𝑢domsuperscriptℎ𝑢𝑧superscriptℎ𝑢𝜈𝜔𝑢\nabla h_{\nu\omega}(z)=\operatorname*{arg\,max}_{u\in\operatorname*{dom}h^{*}}\left\{\langle u,z\rangle-h^{*}(u)-\nu\omega(u)\right\}

is 1/ν1𝜈1/\nu-Lipschitz with respect to ∥⋅∥∗\|{\cdot}\|^{*}, the dual norm to ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\|. Moreover, letting hν​ω≡hsubscriptℎ𝜈𝜔ℎh_{\nu\omega}\equiv h for ν=0𝜈0\nu=0, the smoothing satisfies, for all ν1≥ν2≥0subscript𝜈1subscript𝜈20\nu_{1}\geq\nu_{2}\geq 0,

(ν1−ν2)​infu∈domh∗ω​(u)≤hν2​ω​(z)−hν1​ω​(z)≤(ν1−ν2)​supu∈domh∗ω​(u).subscript𝜈1subscript𝜈2subscriptinfimum𝑢domsuperscriptℎ𝜔𝑢subscriptℎsubscript𝜈2𝜔𝑧subscriptℎsubscript𝜈1𝜔𝑧subscript𝜈1subscript𝜈2subscriptsupremum𝑢domsuperscriptℎ𝜔𝑢\displaystyle(\nu_{1}-\nu_{2})\inf_{u\in\operatorname*{dom}h^{*}}\omega(u)\leq h_{\nu_{2}\omega}(z)-h_{\nu_{1}\omega}(z)\leq(\nu_{1}-\nu_{2})\sup_{u\in\operatorname*{dom}h^{*}}\omega(u)\,.
